creator: Noagels
title: Silicone Devices
materials_required: Fablab or Makerspace's CO2 laser cutter (reference: a 60W Trotec Speedy 100R)
Acrylic/PMMA/plexiglass sheets (enough to cut 2 squares of 280x280mm)
Black vinyl sticker (enough to cut 4 squares of ca 260x260mm)
Mold release spray (Voss Chemie Trennspray,Smooth-on Ease Release)
Liquid metal:Galinstan(best is to keep 10g on hand, depending on how wasteful you are you might use any amount upwards of 5g)
2 pcs 3mldisposable pipetteto take Galinstan from its container onto the stencil
Soft gummi roller (also called rubber brayer)
Silicone primer (Bison Silicone Primertested,3M AP596 adhesion promoter)
A tube ofcheap silicone sealant+ dispenser (caulk gun)
Platinum based 2 component fast curing silicone (Siliconesandmoretested,DragonSkin 10alternative)
3mixing cups(>100ml) andstirring rods(6" is most convenient)
Height reconfigurable blade coater or laser cut DIY version in heights 1mm, 1.5mm and 2mm
description: This instructable details how to create soft and stretchable electronic circuits using silicone, enabling the development of soft robotics and advanced human-computer interfaces. The technique brings technology to the Maker community, allowing for the creation of standalone devices that incorporate microcontrollers, I/O components, and a power source.
steps: Lasercut two rigid carrier plates from clear acrylic, ensuring they are equal in size (280x280mm) and marking the starting plate and transfer plate.

Prepare the starting plate by spraying a thin film of mold release spray, applying a black vinyl sticker (sticky side up), securing it with scotch tape, and applying another layer of mold release spray.
Prepare the transfer plate for selective adhesion by applying a sticker, laser cutting the circuit outline with a 5mm margin, and selectively removing the sticker to expose the underlying plexi.
Place SMD components (resistors and LEDs) according to the circuit design on the starting plate, pushing them firmly into the sticker's adhesive layer.
Apply a thin, uniform layer of Bison Silicone Primer over all exposed parts of the components using an airbrush, and let it dry.

Cast silicone around and over the components by putting an acrylic mastic kit around the silicone sheet perimeter, mixing the platinum silicone, pouring it into the mastic pool, and blade coating to a height 300um > heighest component

Adhere the transfer plate by spraying it with primer, removing the primer mask, mixing more silicone, applying an even layer on the component-filled silicone sheet, aligning the transfer plate (primed side down) with the starting plate, applying pressure, squeezing out air, and waiting for the silicone to cure.
Remove the starting plate by loosening the sticker and carefully peeling it off, checking the components for unobstructed exposure of conductive pads.
Create a stencil mask for the top conductive layer by applying a new sticker, calibrating the laser, cutting the copper circuit traces, and removing the sticker in areas that need to be conductive.

Apply the top conductive layer by cleaning the exposed silicone, using a paint brush to cover all exposed areas with Galinstan, using the roller to create an even coating, recovering excess Galinstan, and removing the sticker stencil carefully.
Prime the component bottoms with a thin layer of Bison Silicone Primer using an airbrush, and let it dry.
Cast and blade coat silicone again to a height of 0.5mm > current stack thickness.
Create a stencil mask for the bottom conductive layer by cutting the bottom copper circuit traces with a laser cutter and removing the sticker in areas that need to be conductive.
Create top-bottom VIAs by calibrating the laser to cut through the silicone, cutting out the VIAs, and removing the silicone to expose the top conductive layer.
Apply the bottom conductive layer with liquid metal, ensuring the stencil adheres well and using a paint brush and roller, making sure top and bottom conductive layers connect through VIA's.
Cast and blade coat silicone again to a height of 500um > current stack thickness.

Create contact pads by calibrating the laser to cut through the silicone and expose copper tape contacts, cutting circuit contacts, removing silicone, cleaning exposed copper pads, and applying solder.

Cut the sample free from the carrier plate by calibrating the laser to cut through the complete silicone stack, cutting the sample outline, and lifting the sample while manually cutting it free from silicone attachments.
Test and admire the device by connecting it to a 5V power supply and observing the LEDs.
